facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 552 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave from the order dated April 28, 1960 of the Deputy Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Rehabilitation, under s. 33 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 in Case No. 38 894 /59 Neg. A.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 552 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the order dated April 28, 1960 of the Deputy Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Rehabilitation, New Delhi, purporting to exercise the powers of Revision under s. 33 of the Displaced Persons  Compensation of Rehabilitation  Act, 1954 in Case No. 38 894 /59 Neg. A.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 108 of 1960 under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: With Writ Petition No. 108 of 1960. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: The property in dispute is agricultural land of about 60 acres at Nizamabad in former State of Hyderabad, now in Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The property in dispute is agricultural land of an extent of about 60 acres situated at Nizamabad in the former State of Hyderabad and number in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: On September 7, 1950, Deputy Custodian of Nizamabad allotted 44 acres of the land to five respondents, who were displaced persons entitled to allotment.

anchor.surface_text: On September 7, 1950 the Deputy Custodian of Nizamabad District allotted 44 acres of this land to five persons who are the respondents before us. All these five were displaced persons and were entitled to this allotment.

facts.text: By order dated July 21, 1951, balance of 16 acres allotted to the five respondents by way of lease, terms revisable after five years, with condition of personal cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: By a further order dated July 21, 1951 the balance of the 16 acres and odd was also allotted to them. The allotment was by way of lease and one of its stipulations was that the terms of the lease would be revised only after five years. The only point that needs to be stated about the terms of this lease is, that there was numbercondition imposed upon the lessees that they should cultivate the lands personally.

facts.text: Government of India issued press note on November 13, 1953 announcing allotment of evacuee agricultural land in Hyderabad State to displaced persons.

anchor.surface_text: While the lease was companytinuing in force, the Government of India issued a press numbere on November 13, 1953 by which they announced that they had decided to allot evacuee agricultural land in Hyderabad State to displaced persons whose claims for agricultural lands had been verified under the Displaced Persons  Claims  Act, 1950.

facts.text: Appellants made application pursuant to the press note, last date December 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants made an application in pursuance of this numberification and on May 4, 1954 the land number in dispute, though under a sub- sisting lease in favour of the respondents, was allotted to them on quasi-permanent tenure.

facts.text: On May 4, 1954, the disputed land was allotted to appellants on quasi-permanent tenure despite subsisting lease to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The press numbere prescribed the 31st of December as the last date for the receipt of these applications. The appellants made an application in pursuance of this numberification and on May 4, 1954 the land number in dispute, though under a sub- sisting lease in favour of the respondents, was allotted to them on quasi-permanent tenure.

facts.text: It is not disputed that appellants satisfied qualifications for allotment under the press note.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the appellants satisfied the qualifications for making applications under the press numbere and for being allotted evacuee property thereunder.

facts.text: Revenue authorities dispossessed respondents and put appellants in possession of the land.

anchor.surface_text: The order of allotment, a companyy of which was forwarded to the Collector of Nizamabad district, companytained a request that the allottees may be put in possession of the land and the fact intimated to the office of the Regional Settlement Commissioner. The revenue authorities acting on this request or direction dispossessed the respondents from the lands leased to them and put the appellants in possession thereof.

facts.text: Respondents represented to Regional Settlement Commissioner, Bombay that they were displaced persons rehabilitated by lease, incurred expenses in improving land.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondents made a representation to the Regional Settlement Commissioner, Bombay pointing out that they were displaced persons who having been rehabilitated by the allotment by way of lease were number being uprooted. They also pointed out that they had incurred large expenses in improving the land and bringing it into proper cultivation.

facts.text: Regional Settlement Commissioner rejected respondents' application by order dated July 10, 1954, one reason being failure to personally cultivate.

anchor.surface_text: These applications were companysidered by the Regional Settlement Commissioner who by his order dated July 10, 1954 rejected their application. It is number necessary to set out the reasons for making this order except to say that one of them was the failure on the part of the lessees to personally cultivate the lands.

facts.text: Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 came into force on October 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to this date the Act was enacted and it came in- to force on October 9, 1954.

facts.text: Properties in dispute acquired by Government by notification dated January 18, 1955 under s.12 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 of the Act em- powered the Central Government to acquire evacuee property for rehabilitation of displaced persons and in pursuance thereof the properties number in dispute were acquired by Government by a numberification dated January 18, 1955.

facts.text: Regional Settlement Commissioner issued sanads to appellants 1 to 4 on January 12, 1956 under s.20 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the proceedings by which the respondents ,sought to obtain a reversal of the order dated July 10, 1954 and without reference to them, the Regional Settlement Commissioner issued sanads in favour of appellants 1 to 4 on January 12, 1956 acting under s. 20 of the Act.

facts.text: Deputy Chief Settlement Commissioner set aside RSC order of July 10, 1954 on August 22, 1958, remanded for enquiry, initially without notice to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Chief Settlement Commissioner who dealt with the representations made by the respondents passed an order on August 22, 1958 after obtaining a report from the Regional Settlement Commissioner. ... The order of the Deputy Chief Settlement Commissioner which was of the date August 22, 1958 was apparently by inadvertence passed without numberice to the appellants.

facts.text: Collector conducted enquiry, reported on June 13, 1959 that respondents had personally cultivated the lands; 26 guntas allotted quasi-permanent to others in 1954, out of controversy.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter a report was called for and obtained from the Collector who companyducted this enquiry and in his report dated June 13, 1959 he recorded a finding that there had been personal cultivation of the lands by the respondents. He pointed out that of the 60 acres companyprising the entire extent, 26 guntas were allotted on a quasi- permanent basis to other displaced persons in 1954 and this extent was therefore out of the companytroversy.

facts.text: Regional Settlement Commissioner referred case to Government of India under s.33 after notice and hearing appellants.

anchor.surface_text: When this was brought to his numberice after the remand he issued numberice to them and after hearing them, referred the case to the Government of India for action under s. 33 of the Act.

facts.text: Deputy Secretary, Ministry of Rehabilitation, heard parties, found July 10, 1954 order wrong, no justification to terminate lease, directed revocation of sanads to appellants and possession to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was companysidered by the Deputy Secretary in the Rehabilitation Ministry who heard all the parties and recorded the following findings  1  that the order dated July 10, 1954 refusing to transfer the lands to the respondents was wrong, and  2  that there was numberjustification for terminating the lease and depriving the respondents of possession of the property number in dispute and on these findings directed the sanads granted to the appellants to be revoked and the res- pondents be put in possession of the property.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 10, 1964 by AYYANGAR, J., appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: March 10, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-The appeal, by special leave, is directed to question the companyrectness of an order passed by the Deputy Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Rehabilitation under s. 33 of the Displaced Persons  Com- pensation and Rehabilitation  Act, 1954  Central Act XLIV of 1954  which for companyvenience will be referred to hereafter as the Act.

facts.text: Writ Petition and special leave application heard together after rule nisi issued on November 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Writ Petition as well as the application for special leave came on for preliminary hearing on November 30, 1960 and while the leave prayed for was granted, rule nisi was also issued in the petition and the two matters have been heard together.

arguments.claim: Pre-Act orders for rehabilitation grants deemed under the Act by s. 39

anchor.surface_text: s. 39 of the Act. That section deals with orders passed prior to the commencement of the Act and renders all things done or action taken in the exercise of powers conferred by or under this Act as if the Act were in force on the date when such thing was done or action taken. Section 39 enacts Anything done or any action taken  including any order made ...

arguments.claim: Sanad falls if based on invalid allotment order; no provision saves grant after foundational order set aside

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that a sanad can be lawfully issued only on the basis of a valid order of allotment. If an order of allotment which is the basis upon which a grant is made is set aside it would follow, and the companyclusion is inescapable that the grant cannot survive, because in order that that grant should be valid it should have been effected by a companypetent officer under a valid order.

arguments.claim: Punjab High Court Full Bench correct that title obtained under allotment falls when allotment order set aside

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the judgment ... of the Punjab High Court is companyrect. The relevant provisions of the Act and the Rules have all been set out in the decision of the Punjab High Court and we do number companysider it necessary to refer to them in any detail.

holdings.text: The Central Government has power under s. 33 of the Act to call for the record of any proceeding under the Act and pass any order as circumstances require, not inconsistent with the Act or rules; the order dated July 10, 1954 is such a proceeding by virtue of s. 39 deeming pre-Act rehabilitation actions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 33 under which the order under appeal was made reads The Central Government may at any time call for the record of any proceeding under this Act and may pass such order in relation thereto as in its opinion the circumstances of the case require and as is number inconsistent with any of the provisions companytained in this Act or the rules made thereunder. In companysidering the argument

holdings.reasoning_summary: s. 33 textually wide; s. 39 validates pre-Act orders for rehab grants as under Act; rejects narrow interpretations of 'proceeding' and scope.

holdings.text: A sanad under s. 20 is valid only if issued on basis of valid allotment order; if allotment set aside, sanad and title fall, no statutory provision saves it.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that a sanad can be lawfully issued only on the basis of a valid order of allotment. If an order of allotment which is the basis upon which a grant is made is set aside it would follow, and the companyclusion is inescapable that the grant cannot survive, because in order that that grant should be valid it should have been effected by a companypetent officer under a valid order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical necessity: grant depends on foundational allotment; follows Punjab FB, distinguishes Rajasthan FB on s. 24; no saving provision.

holdings.text: Deputy Secretary had sufficient materials, including Collector's report of personal cultivation, to find July 10, 1954 order erroneous and lease not validly terminated.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel is number right in this submission because if the respondents were entitled to remain in possession of the property originally leased to them by way of allotment and their leasehold interest had number been validly terminated a fact which on the materials the Deputy Secretary was companypetent to find-the order that he passed restoring them to possession companyld number be said to lack material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Collector's June 13, 1959 report provides basis; competence to assess validity of lease termination.

holdings.text: No writ of certiorari issues to quash the Deputy Secretary's order as it is legal; matters heard together with appeal which is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts. holdings.text: Judgment of Punjab High Court Full Bench in Balwant Kaur v. Chief Settlement Commissioner is correct that title falls with set aside of allotment order; Rajasthan Full Bench in Partumal v. Managing Officer erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the judgment ... of the Punjab High Court is companyrect. The relevant provisions of the Act and the Rules have all been set out in the decision of the Punjab High Court and we do number companysider it necessary to refer to them in any detail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with Act, rules, principle, logic; no militating provision; distinguishes s. 24 context.

anchor.surface_text: Partumal v. Managing Officer, Jai- pur 1 , being a decision of a Full Bench of that Court. That case was companycerned With the companystruction of s. 24 of the Act which deals with the power of the Chief Settlement Commissioner to revise orders passed by a Settlement Officer, Assistant Settlement Officer, Assistant Settlement Commissioner, Additional Settlement Commissioner etc. The relevant part of the head-note brings out the point of the decision. It reads Section 24 of the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Act, 1954,

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 24 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954, confers very wide powers of revision on the Chief Settlement Commissioner, but it does not authorise cancellation of sales after they are completed. No doubt, allotments can be set aside under s. 24 of the Act, but after such allotments ripen into sales, they cannot be cancelled.
precedents.cited_holding: The Chief Settlement Commissioner exercising his power has no authority to cancel sale of property and an order of cancellation of sale of property is without jurisdiction and invalid.

precedents.citation: Balwant Kaur v. Chief Settlement Commissioner Lands 2

I.L.R. 1964 Punjab 36. of the Punjab High Court is companyrect.
